151242477.review:
Amazing.  TLDR: Feels like Undertale, but actually playable for a non-gamer like myself.  

To elaborate, I found this similar to Undertale because: 
-  Dialogue changes with reapers before and after doing an action.  
-  The player gains vast empathy for ghosts and reapers alike.  
-  Hidden areas.
-  Just plain vibes.  (I know, its just my "raised-by-the-internet brain rot."  Sue me.)

It is unlike Undertale because:
-  The battle system is speed based decision making through a menu, instead of a bullet hell.
-  Short and sweet game.
-  Personified player character.
-  While there are different endings to Grimm's Hollow, its no where NEAR as complex as Undertale's paths.  This is a good thing!  It can be kind of frustrating if each ending requires specific specifications, and if you mess up, its all over.  Grimm's Hollow is therefore vastly easier to consume, and as a non-gamer, its a welcome change.  

Will be replaying many times over.  Love it!

148194279.review:
(There will be NO SPOILERS in this review)
This game is incredible, it has a few flaws, but for its price (or lack there of) the quality is incredible with a deep story line and lovable characters. It has touched my heart in many ways and will definitely be one of my favorite games for a while.

Starting with the positives, the music and visuals were amazing. I was shocked when I first opened the game to be greeted with visuals almost resembling that of Undertale and Deltarune, which cost much more than Grimm's Hollow. The tutorial is very helpful, and guides you through very nicely instead of just leaving you to figure it out. As the game progresses and you gain more abilities, you can discover your own combinations for combat styles, and there is no 'one way' to defeat any enemy. I won't spoil anything, but the ending is truly moving and climactic, and feels really worth it after all you've worked for in the game. It leaves a lot of answered yet unanswered questions, and resolves the game just enough for it to be satisfying, but also leaves it open ended to leave you wanting more. The game has very good pacing with its story and has just the right balance between game play and plot. It finds a way to fit quirky, light characters into a personal and deep story.
Some negatives of the game mainly involve the controls. When I first started, I found the dodging mechanic to be quite finicky and inconsistent. This made some fights quite frustrating as I was unable to dodge enemies attacks and avoid taking damage. This skill is especially crucial toward the end of the game, which makes the wonky mechanic quite annoying. 
At some points of the game, I also felt a lack of direction. I didn't know where I was meant to go half the time, and found myself just wandering around in circles until I found an area to progress in. Although this definitely could be a personal issue, it really fed into my play time of me just running around directionless. 

Overall, I would 100% recommend this game. Although it has some slight flaws, they definitely can and will be overlooked once you dive into the wholesome little world Grimm's Hollow has to offer. It has a compelling story and lovable, quirky characters who will all find a place in your heart. It has a nice playtime of 3-4 hours, and is a lovely way to spend an afternoon. And since it's free, what do you have to loose?

This is an amazing game. That's all there is to it. The art style is lovely, its completely free (unless you want to play the DLC, which, you absolutely will), the story is richer than homemade apple pie.. and the writing is some of the best I've ever seen. The only bad thing about it are the unskippable, long dialogue lines, but it only gets annoying after the second or third playthrough, so you barely even notice. This is just one of those games that you need to experience before you die.

146350613.review:
I liked the game overall: cool character design, coherent aesthetics and a simple but still good story; the ending in particular was a great climax.

The music was mostly good, with the exception of the last zone (not boss) where it was missing sometimes.

Unfortunately, I didn't enjoy the combat very much. It's a turn based game in the Final Fantasy style, which means everyone charges their turn with time. Nothing new but that's fine for a little game like this; the problem I had with this system's application was completely technical: it didn't feel very polished since enemies still charge attacks while SOME of your menus are open; this means enemies can attack you with quick-time moves (that you dodge with timing) while you are about to select something. This is especially annoying when the enemies are faster since they make the menus feel slow. This isn't helped by the fact that the attack button (Z) is buffered (which means activates after the enemy finished the attack) but other buttons aren't, so you easily pick the wrong option. Another thing that feels like a bug is the fact that buffs you use on yourself... can miss?? WHY?! Or, again, attacks that you did correctly with the slider... can actually miss. That is a system which lies to the player.

The other reason combat didn't feel very exciting was how stats work: from what I understood, defence is a flat reduction of damage... which makes the stats more important that any possible strategy. An exception to this could be Poison... which I didn't bother to use since doubling attack and defence with Specials was an auto-win in every fight; you can even use Haste and Sleep/stuns for more turn economy on top of that and go almost infinite with Quick Attack.

But don't get fooled by the lenght of this post: the game IS good (for the points I covered at the beginning) but it simply isn't very fun to play for how it is structured.

144647759.review: Grimm's Hollow is a 2-hour-long narrative RPG about death that I wish I loved. In a word, this game is "cute." Its morbidly whimsical tone lends itself very well to the subject matter of the game, covering the story of Lavender's afterlife efforts to bring her brother Timmy, stranded in the world of the dead, back to life. My issue with the game is everything that surrounds the story. Grimm's Hollow feels like it was originally developed as two separate games - a short visual novel and a short Undertale-inspired RPG - and those two games had to fit both of their contents into the runtime of only one of them. A majority of the game is spent dungeon crawling in a derivative, if servicable ATB combat system. The gameplay is fine, and the art direction, character design, and music come together to elevate the experience. Were the game to consist of just this, it would have been fine. However, as a result of the high-concept narrative and the short runtime, dialogue and story scenes are dumped unceremoniously onto the player, in jarring scenes that lack cohesive progression. It's a shame, because what's there is actually really damn good, and with a little bit of a longer runtime it could have really won me over, but it's a free indie game, so I can't exactly criticize it for that. The game has four endings, only two of which I found narratively satisfying, and costs $0. It's worth a playthrough, and I look forward to what Ghosthunter (the developer) comes out with next. 7/10.

143294543.review:
It's a cute and short game. for a free game, you get some nice narrative, a nice grinding mechanic plus fighting mechanic. Nice to sit down and chill for a while. The story is also very nice, I love the characters, especially Grimm and how fatherly he acts.

I think, one thing I'd wish better is that they fix a bit more of the turn-based part of the game. I like the fact there aren't really turns, per say. But sometimes, it gets difficult to understand. Especially at the beginning, when you don't have your speed raised up, most of the time you just stand waiting your 'turn' and wondering why you are receiving so much damage. In a way, it's nice because it teaches you how to level up the right stats. But it does seem a bit unbalanced, since at the beginning you're too slow and get too damaged, and at the end you're too fast and there's barely a challenge.

Also, sometimes, the 'evade' mechanic glitches as well. Sometimes you get the 'evade' bar while you're in the menu to choose your attack. And at the end it's not a difference, since you're already high leveled and has some extra wp in you. But at the beginning you can easily die by that.

Other than that, it's a really cool game, fun to play, and welcoming for both the ones who just want to play the game for its story and the ones who want to play for the RPG style.

Que esta gemita sea gratuita y esté en español para que todos la puedan probar es una bendición que todos deberían vivir.

No me gustan los juegos de pixel, ni con combates por turnos, pero es que esta es una de esas exepciones que te atrapa aunque no seas el tipo de audiencia que frecuneta estos juegos

[h1]Lo BUENO[/h1]
+Un juego con mucha personalidad. Te incentiva a explorar cada rincón del mapa.

+La historia es cautivadora, te mantiene con ganas de saber más.

+La banda sonora es hermosa.

[h1]Lo MALO[/h1]
-Me habría gustado que fuese más largo. Me cautivó todo el mundo que crearon como para que sea tan corto.

-No está habilitada la interfaz de Steam dentro del juego, por lo que no podrás sacar capturas, por ejemplo.

¡RECOMENDADÍSIMO!

Grimm's Hollow is a captivating freeware RPG that takes you on an otherworldly adventure in the afterlife. The game's charming visuals, touching storyline, and clever characters make it an absolute delight to play. Reap ghosts, explore haunted caves, and uncover the game's secrets as you search for your missing brother. 👻💫

What's even more magical is that this enchanting journey won't cost you a dime - it's entirely FREE! 💸 Despite its short playtime, Grimm's Hollow offers multiple endings, tactical combat, and rewarding exploration, ensuring a memorable experience for players. The engaging community around the game adds to its charm. ✨

If you're a fan of RPGs or simply enjoy heartwarming storytelling, don't miss out on Grimm's Hollow. It's a gem that deserves to be celebrated! Spread the word and share the magic of this captivating RPG. 🗣️🎮✨

142448027.review: I've been on an RPG Maker kick for a little while recently and this was at the top of the list of games to play. I can see why. It's fun, it's free, it's cute, it has a good soundtrack, it will entertain you for around 3 hours and the gameplay hardly becomes stale (like it can with so many other RPGs if enough attention isn't paid to how generic the player's experience is. Looking at you, Alpha Kimori and second phase Columbine RPG.) With a varied cast of both allies and enemies, every new area is fresh and full of secrets to explore, plus healing items and skills galore. There are so many different skills you may very well not end up utilizing all of them, but making your own playstyle out of them works fine too. There is a small amount of grinding for the best ending [spoiler](fill out that skill tree!)[/spoiler] but nothing too serious and totally worth it even if it makes basically any enemy really easy. At that point in the game you're best off completing it anyway.

141194082.review:
A sweet and charming short JRPG with a touching story and surprisingly complex battle system for a 3-hour game.

The strongest aspect of this game is its theme — morbid cute. It ties everything together, from the visuals (look at the protagonst's black void of an eyes and try saying they are not cute), to mechanics (sweets instead of health potions (what health, you're dead)), to characters (the Grimm Reaper him(?)self likes tea, chocolate cakes and knitting).
The thing is, death is scary. The thought of death is scary, especially after the fact. It's only natural to hide from it, behind baloons, sweets, and literal masks. The game is very aware of that, and it's at its best when it acknowladges it to the player. 
I enjoyed my time the most when characters engaged in (heartfelt and witty) conversations. Grimm's Hollow has a limited cast, but every single one of them is full of personality and is very loveable.
But other than that the game has a lot to offer. It's tactical combat is not the deepest there is, but for such a short runtime, it has a lot of variety in enemies, weapons and tactics. 
The game even has several endings!
The only criticism I might have is with the implementation of QTE mechanics. Or even one exact mechanc of parrying. It took some time for me to figure out how it works, and it is extremely important for a final fight. I wish it was explained in the manual, and not only in the tutorial. 
Oh, yes, the game even has a manual!

As a busy adult player with a gamer's burnout, I am really glad that games like this exist. It will make you laugh, it will make you think, both tactically and existentianally, and it will make you fall in love with its characters. And all of that in just one evening.

140670460.review:
El juego tiene una historia bonita y simplona, además de 4 posibles finales, pero tiene 2 problemas enormes que le quitan mucho.

El primero es el combate. Es muy parecido al de Undertale, aunque mucho más tosco. Muchas veces vas a hacer el mismo daño o más en la zona naranja que en la blanca, pero luego igual haces 20 veces menos, cuando según el propio tutorial, debería hacer siempre la mitad de tu daño total si estás en esa zona, Alguien podría argumentar que es porque haces crítico, pero realmente no hay muchos indicadores de ello, y se siente más aleatorio que otra cosa, Las zonas roja y negra funcionan bien, eso sí. Además, sobre el final de juego el combate es básicamente un chiste. Sé que el foco del juego es la historia, pero ese comienzo tan absurdamente complicado en el que un plumazo te mata y ese final en el que los enemigos hacen 0 de daño no se entiende.

La segunda queja, y la más importante, es la de la traducción. No puedes cambiar el idioma del juego. Se asigna automáticamente dependiendo del idioma de tu Steam. Yo lo tengo en castellano de España, y lo más cercano que tiene el juego es el de LATAM. Bien. Mi queja no es porque "unga bunga traducción latina caca". Eso me da igual. El problema es que la traducción latina tiene una calidad de vergüenza. Estamos hablando de una traducción oficial, no de una fan translation, donde se entienden más estos errores. Sinceramente, da la sensación de que el que haya hecho esto, ha ido al traductor de Google a "hacer" el trabajo. Hay miles de comas donde no toca, más palabras mal escritas que bien, ya sea por acentos que faltan, sobran, o están mal puestos, o por palabras directamente mal escritas en las que igual hay una b donde va una v. No solo esto, sino que se nota que el texto estaba originalmente en inglés, pues hay traducciones literales de expresiones como "oh my god", o el uso excesivo de pronombres que caracteriza al inglés, y no digo ninguna tontería de "oh no ha usado elle". Quiero decir que literalmente la palabra que más vas a leer es "él". Y hay mil ejemplos más como estos.

Sé que el juego es gratis, y que en definitiva es una experiencia disfrutable, pero eso no significa que no podamos exigir calidad y criticar mierdas de este estilo. Si tienes ganas de probarlo, no te vas a arrepentir, pero al menos ve con la mentalidad de que hay cosas que se pueden mejorar.

139642112.review:
A cute little indie RPG game that is free to download and play so I thought I'd give it a go. I will say its a decent game for a free title and it has multiple endings which does give it some replay value. The story was simple, but still emotional and effective. I love the art style too with a cool pixel art and it reminded me of Undertale in a way. It also has a nice progression system as you get spirit essence from all the ghosts you kill and can spend that on unlocking new abilities or upgrade your base stats. I found this to be very satisfying and I got a rush when I had collected enough to do a bunch of upgrades all at once.

Combat was where it gets interesting and in my case a little frustrating. Whenever you do basic attacks, you have a little gauge meter with a reticle moving and you have to hit it in the middle in order to perform successful attacks. You need to do this also to build up your magic meter so you can eventually perform your more powerful abilities. Enemies will attack and some attacks you will be able to dodge by way of the same gauge mechanic. Because of that its a game where you have to pay attention during combat otherwise you can easily get wiped. What I don't like about this battle system is that it tends to feel like a mix of turn based and real time, as sometimes when the menu you pops up for you to select your next move, enemies can still attack you. There were so many times where my menu would pop up, but I found it better to just wait a few extra seconds for the dodge mechanic to come up so I could do that first before attacking. It just got really frustrating after a while and sometimes it was inconsistent as I would hit the middle of the gauge but the enemy would still hit me or I would miss my attack. Plus at the end, during the final boss fight, they throw in a third mechanic that you have to contend with that I can't talk about because its a bit of a story spoiler. It got really irritating having to manage 3 different mechanics during an intense fight, where all I really wanted to do was just take my time and plan what my next move would be. I would have much preferred that they made it so that you dodge during the enemies turn and then do the attack mechanic during your turn.

Overall, its still a solid game to mess around with and its free so I won't knock it too much, despite my frustrations.

139385458.review:
It was alright. I'd give it a solid 4/5.
Positives: Sountrack and sound design were fantastic, sounds really helped add to the atmosphere. Character design was adorable and spooky cozy. Battles were appropriately balanced, if not a bit on the easy side, which I think is always nice if you're trying to complete a stat grid or grind. The diversity of the attacks was well rounded, though it would've been nice to have the ghosts have a wider range of attack styles; evading attacks did get tedious in the end. Overall, perfect spooky atmosphere with solid gameplay.
Feedback: I didn't really care about the story or the characters, personally. Partly that could've been because I was expecting a longer game, but after playing other games that explore death and mourning, this one didn't hit the mark for me. I really didn't care by the end and didn't feel like playing it for a different ending. The pacing was a bit too fast and I would've been content with more times spent in the dungeons. Also, there was some moralizing about in-world things that...fell a bit flat for me since as a player I wasn't given an option to not do the thing being moralized about. 
Overall, I would tell people to play this game for the atmosphere and a fun, decently easy, dungeon romp. Maybe they might be more invested in the story than I was, who knows! I did like it and would love to see more either in this world or from this dev.

139300734.review:
This game is genuinely touching in a way very few games have managed to achieve to me. It almost got me to cry. (For me, that's saying a lot.)
It's not the longest game out there, taking me 3-ish hours to beat, (with me taking my sweet time looking at every detail,) but I think that's to its benefit. It doesn't try to be more than it needs to be. It says what it wants to say, does what it wants to do, and then its done. No more, no less. I'd say it's very effective, in that way.

I'd say this game is right up there with Oneshot and Undertale. If you liked those games, you'll love this one. (Personally, I found it more fun than Undertale, but that's just me.)
I'd like to see more from this developer. They have the potential to make amazing experiences, as shown here.

(And no, my username has nothing to do with this game. It was quite jarring when I first saw the name of the main character. Not the games fault, of course. It's a good name.)

I know this review isn't the most well put together, but trust me: This game is worth trying. It really is. 10/10.

Absolutely fantastic game. I've just finished the "casual" mode, which I picked since I prefer story to combat in games. The design, combat, and story are spellbinding. I swear I got sucked right into the world itself. It is a very honest and yet relatively gentle depiction of grief, the best depiction I've ever personally seen. My one and only regret is this: of the two (of four) endings I found in my short time playing, both have me thinking about the grief I have tucked away myself. Grief is rough, and this game acknowledges that, and embraces at least some of the ways that people end up dealing with their grief. It gave me some food for thought. And personally? I have a feeling that my experience with this game might have nudged me a little closer to finding peace with my grief.

anyways... 15/10. Absolutely recommend.

137507770.review:
This was such an amazing game. I was looking for something short enough to pass the time. I wound up going for a 2nd, better ending because- well, you'd have to play the game to find out, hehe. And it wasn't too difficult to play the normal difficulty, either. I felt like it was just right for a short and casual, yet story-driven game. I love the world building, even though it isn't that massive, and I enjoy the lore. The music and art are lovely, and it was overall a great experience.

EDIT: Regarding the combat system, I will agree with some of the critiques. It wasn't immediately clear why the ghosts were still able to attack me while I was on my own attack menu. To me, this kind of removed the point of calling it "turn based". It was really a matter of using Spirit Energy to level your stats such as health, damage, speed, etc. Like, upping your speed will help plenty.

Similarly, my dodge would not go through even if I could swear I hit the Down arrow on time. This feature is not found in the manual, so I just had to live with it and I got by through improving my stats. Speaking of which - I didn't really use most of the skills. I used some where applicable (Slash on multiple enemies), but apart from that, I mostly stuck to the default attack and Pierce. Every now and then, I'd try out one of the other skills but I'd forget about them later on.

It's not a perfect game, but it's better than many free to play games on here. And my points from earlier still stand, I still enjoyed the world (albeit small), the bit of lore we had, and the story.

135752613.review:
This game is absolutely beautiful.

(SPOILERS)

I'd say that the story is the best part of this game. This game is the only game that got me close to tears when I played it. For such a short game (about 2-3 hours for me), it envelopes you into the story quickly and it does it so well. If this was any other game, with this incredibly short playtime I wouldn't give a shit about Lavender and her brother. All the characters are so likable. Lavander, Timmy, Grimm. Hell, I could kind of sympathize for the baker. (The antagonist of the story) But the cherry on top were the endings. Except for when I played Undertale, I have never been so satisfied and sad with the endings. All 4 of them almost left me in tears. Especially the bad ending. The combination of some of them being so bitter-sweet yet so fulfilling scratches an itch I never knew I had.

The art style and animation is unique and very well polished. In many games like these the art style usually lacks emotion and depth, but here it just works. And the animation is very smooth as well.

The music is surprisingly catchy and nice to listen to coming from an indie game.

The combat system surprisingly never gets boring. This is because of the incredibly short length of the game. Its simple but complicated enough at the same time.

I am so happy I stumbled across this game. 
10\10 This is a must play.

133959849.review:
Grimm’s Hollow has a few of the elements of many RPG games, the game is a top view 2D indie game in which the main character moves on x and y axis and the combat starts when Lavender collides with ghosts that are fluctuating around the map; the movements are fast and the player doesn’t get annoyed by the movement system since it’s not complex and understandable; The player, moved by a feeling of discovery, is pushed to explore multiple locations and caves looking for secrets and pick ups useful for the combats. This element is even strengthened by the presence of secret walls that can be found by clicking the action button on normal walls, once the player finds the right spot, the wall tears apart leaving a secret access. Not only this highlights a sense of discovery but it also creates a small loop where the player, in order to have advantages in combat, is pushed to find new secret passages, kill the mobs, get the treasure and get out.

The combat system is modeled on a standard role playing game system that has been around for many years. Once Lavender collides with the ghosts the combat starts, the player can choose among four actions: swing, special, pocket and flee. The swing is the basic attack, the special is the special attack, the pocket refers to the inventory where the player can choose among different items to use in the combat and flee is used to attempt to run away. Even if the combat system looks like many other role playing games systems, the fight is made a little bit more fun by the addition of real time components. When the player chooses to swing the attack bar pops up and the player has to press the action button at the right moment if he wants to increase the attack damage. The same component is used also for the enemy attack, some of the enemies can be countered by actively pressing the action button at the right moment in order to dodge the damage. This gives the player not only a phase of planning and strategy but also a phase of real time playing. In such a sense, the player feels more engaged and needs to rely both on his planning and active skills.

Grimm’s Hollow also presents a few loops even if the main story is straight and clear: Lavender has to find her brother through the realm while hunting souls. During the game the player has to engage enemies in order to upgrade Lavender’s talent tree and eventually be able to face stronger and stronger enemies. At the beginning of the game, the player has to die a few times before understanding the game mechanics, in particular when and how using items during the fight and 	which talents to upgrade first. In such a sense the game flow is not well balanced giving to the player a sense of anxiety as soon as Lavender faces the first few ghosts; at the beginning just a few ghosts can kill the player if he doesn’t make the right choices or choosing and purchasing the right items that can make him win the fights. On the other hand, as the game progresses, the player finds the combats easier and most of the time, boring.

Among all components the story is the element that stands out the most; Lavender wakes up in a bed, dead and surrounded by strangers in skeleton mask while she got herself a job as a reaper. The story is funny and made more interesting by the many dialogues that the player can experience along the game. Even if the story looks foregone on the surface, it hides a more complex and a deeper plot that is not given. Another point that makes the story a bit fun is the introduction of sarcastic components from the very beginning; the developer wants to tell a story that sounds sad but makes the player have fun while experiencing it. The player is pushed again by a sense of discovery, he wants to progress in the game to find out more about Lavender and Timmy’s story, a deep fairy tale story.

The loops are shallow and not complex and this makes the player experiencing the game only once; players, once they finish the game, are not pushed to come back to replay it because the goals are very straightforward and easy to reach. The developer uses an expedient to create the game more interesting for players that not only are driven by a sense of discovery but also for players that are driven by a sense of achievement; the story has four different endings that can be unlocked by replaying the game.

In conclusion, the game design is shallow on an aesthetic point of view, even if it has many role playing game components, these components are not complex and the flow of the game is not balanced. The game is eventually easy to learn and beat. The story, on the other hand, is a component that makes players keep playing driven by a feeling of discovery. The audience of the game is focused on casual players that may or may not be used to RPG mechanics and they would like to discover more about Lavender story.

133619625.review:
This has been in my wishlist for a while, I heard it was a good game but never really had the time to sit down with it. Today I remembered its existence and decided to finally give it a try.

When I tell you I couldn't put it down, I mean it. I was blown away by just how charming and sweet (pun intended!) the world was. The concept of the afterlife is genius, and the synergy between ghosts and reapers made it impossible to stop smiling. It's been a long time since I've vibed with a game. I don't know if I've missed any secrets, but I plan on going through it again just to make sure! 

The story was bittersweet, but so is life. In the end, I couldn't help but feel hopeful. The creators did not have to go as hard as they did on a free game, but the fact that they did goes to show just how much they enjoyed working on this project. 

This is an experience I will never forget. Thank you for giving me so much to think about, and for letting me experience this story for myself.

131855533.review:
A very sweet, cute little game! Sweet, but also [i]bitter[/i]sweet - though I wouldn't say it's super sad (at least not [i]most[/i] of the endings; watching [spoiler]Timmy lose himself and become a hostile ghost is rather distressing[/spoiler] , and [spoiler]I think the 'best' ending, so to speak, is the one that made me cry the absolute most[/spoiler] ) but it definitely made me at least tear up regardless; there's a heavy sense of melancholy without being oppressive. There were also one or two surprises for me as I played through. There were also some giggly moments, which made a nice lighter balance. The music was a lovely fit for it, emotive and rarely taking centre stage, and the sound effects in general not disruptive or irritatingly repetitive when playing straight through (as I often find RPG sound effects to be).

It took me about an hour and a half to get to (one of the) ending(s) the first time, and I've gone back to play through the others as well.

I played on casual mode (partly because I [i]was[/i] more interested in the story than combat, partly because I played it on no sleep for days) but I found the combat well laid out. I did have an occasional issue with "evade" failing even when I hit it properly, I think (as another reviewer mentioned) because there were other menus up for my own attack at the same time; it wasn't nearly every time and it wasn't enough to be a real disruption to my combat or my enjoyment of the game, though I did level up my willpower (health) a bit, early, to allow for it just in case. I barely unlocked any of the spells (only the one that allows you to steal your opponent's WP and the AOE slash) and went for a barebones combat method (only levelling up strength, defense, willpower, speed, and special) that worked just fine for everything up to and including the boss fight, at least in casual mode. ([spoiler]Though I then had to grind a little bit - not too long really - to max out everything to complete Lavender's soul so I could get to all the endings.[/spoiler])

131448092.review:
Sometimes when I lay down at night, I worry about how I'll eventually die. My existence is just another small blink in the universe, and even the most optimistic side of me feels like I should prepare for death (in case immortality doesn't get discovered somehow). I get the feeling that I'm not the only one who's had thoughts about reaching that point, and I think others, like the creator of this game, have thought about it too. 

Grimm's Hollow takes place in the afterlife, the characters (now dead) have time to reflect on their lives in a manner they were unable to during while they drew breath on Earth. Waking up to an unfamiliar world, they are left hunting down a soul for a chance to "pass through a gate", one which leads to a place just as unknown. Chasing the dream of living once more, they search while climbing over the corpses of those who oppose them, not shying away from what the aftermath of that conflict implies. What few memories the residents of the world have left from amnesia are cherished, and companionship is sought after in order to have the occasional bit of levity, something brought over from the living world.

I went into this as a casual player and I enjoyed it. There’s definitely effort put into this because the music, the visual and story was great. The only issues I had was in the combat, in particularly when the dodge prompt for an enemy attack appeared. It seems to not always work. My guess it that it may have to do with the fact it happens right in the middle of when I’m already selecting an option in the menu. It can’t process both actions so you end up either failing to dodge or not getting out an attack. 

Oh, and sometimes when you’re doing a strike attack and you have to click on the down arrow to get it into the middle bar, it tends to skip/lag like it's dropping frames. That was annoying, but not as bad compared to the dodging prompt.

For a free game this was lovely! The slight issue in combat doesn’t break the game or make it impossible to finish. You just need patience, stock up on health items and I figured out that once I max out the entire skill tree it was easier to get through. Seriously, max it out in the beginning or before you get to the final cave.

Story: The story is actually pretty good, I really like it - yet of course It can't be masterpiece with only 2–3 hours long, but still, the way the story is told in the game and the story itself is fine, emotional package.

Game-play: It's fun, but the mechanics whatever are using the game are not for too short games - if the game was at least 5–8 hours, it was possible even to compete for some indie awards. I'm talking specifically for the RPG mechanics - you have many choices, but after all you actually have almost everything. And in a 2-hour game, you can't feel the consequences of bad decisions because they're not possible. 

Difficulty: They're two possible difficulties, but I don't think anyone will make difference between the two - this is drawback in my opinion because I found out that the game have 4 possible endings, which are dependable on how the last fight progress. But because it's so easy, you should be either badly or very unlucky to actually reach a different ending from the standard one.

Music: I don't I can say much about it, it was gorgeous.

129282998.review:
Overall: 7.3/10
Recommended: sure 
  (free, quick, and interesting setting, with 4 endings)
Time to complete story+extras: 2.75 hrs
   (Med-Fast read speed, mostly upgraded protagonist, explored everything)
Time to 100%: 3.75 hrs
   (1 playthru with a bit of grinding (to max character for 2 of the endings), all 4 endings, all dialogue read)
Controller compatible: I don't believe it does
   (I had to set up a KBM to gamepad configuration in antimicro (program), similar to RPG Maker games)

Story: 7.5/10
  + interesting setting, premise, and primary objective for the game
  ~ primary objective was reached a bit quicker than expected, which didn't allow the world to be as developed and interesting
Gameplay: 7.3/10
  + timing-based attacks and dodges mixed with selecting skills for the combat was interesting
  + upgrades to the protagonist had a clear effect on the combat, and the difficulty is somewhat based on you balancing stats vs skill unlocks
  ~ it seems like the turn-based pattern to the combat is either buggy or is actually somewhat real-time, because the enemy would often get extra attacks if I didn't immediately open a menu to select a new attack or skill (this didn't seem fair or enjoyable since our attacks are strictly once per turn)
Characters: 7.5/10
  + enjoyable characters with some development and upbeat jokes
  + interesting characterization of the Grim Reaper
Graphics: 6.5/10
  + somewhat nostalgic and on the "cute" side, which helped make the setting less depressing and fit the story
  ~ the art style is somewhat muddy, washed out, and underdeveloped, making some things hard to decipher what they are and not having a lot of details
Audio: 7.3/10
  + fit the setting, with the sound effects and music adding to the experience
UI: 6.5/10
  ~ limited to screen size and audio settings, and a bit limiting in navigating the menus

Score comparison:
HLtB:         7.4/10 (64 votes)
Metacritic: 9.1/10 (only 16)
Steam:       98% positive (10,526)

127343627.review:
I would have given a stellar review if it weren't for the broken mechanics on the final boss level. 

The game is gorgeous. I think it's insane this game is free and would be worth at least a few bucks. The time and effort put into it are clear, and it's a great little gem. 

The fight mechanics take a bit to get used to, but they're fun and challenging. I ended up switching to casual mode as the time-sensitive nature combined with a somewhat trial-by-fire learning of the controls (I read the manual but it's hard to perform a new task under pressure) made me want to go easy. That helped the game greatly, and I could breeze through it and enjoy the story. 

The final boss fight is when everything was lost for me. 

**Minor spoilers**

The final fight involves a two "person" battle where you must juggle switching between characters with the enemies' fast-paced attacks. As this was the first battle with a second player, the controls suddenly became confusing and difficult to manage. 

I struggled to figure out how to switch characters and fight and what to do with my new buddy in combat. Since it was the final boss it was high stakes and I spent so much time panicking trying to switch characters and attack while balancing defense that it made it a frustrating and impossible task. There is a small possibility that I am dumb, and there was a simple solution, but either way, this turned me off of the game. I loved it so much that it was disappointing to see the ending pulled out from under me because of bogged-down mechanics. 

I hope this is something relatively easy to fix (like introducing p2 a little earlier into combat). I really did enjoy the rest of it, and it's hard to complain about something free. Just can't recommend the game with the wonky end mechanics.

No soy fan de los RPG y éste juego me ha encantado. La parte que más me desagrada de estos juegos son los combates por turnos, y aún así, al no ser muy largo el juego y no tener que enfrentar muchas peleas se me hizo muy llevadero.

Sin querer hacer spoiler el juego trata temas como la muerte, traumas familiares, y principalmente se centra en la relación de los 2 hermanos protagonistas del juego.

Existen 4 finales diferentes pudiendo hacerse 2 de ellos en unas 2 horas y teniendo que dedicarle más tiempo para acceder a los otros 2 aunque no sé exactamente cuanto tiempo puede ser, ya que debemos ganar más "experiencia" con nuestro personaje y por tanto tendremos que librar más peleas con el consiguiente aumento de tiempo.

Aunque a lo largo de la historia se van dibujando pinceladas de la historia de los hermanos, no es hasta el final donde uno queda realmente conmovido y te das cuenta que mereció la pena cada segundo que dedicaste a jugarlo.

Me extraña que no haya tenido más repercusión el juego ya que para mí es mucho mejor que otros tantos que hay por ahí que no son Free to Play. Un maravilloso juego en resumen. Bajenlo, que es gratis.

124249413.review:
Grimm's Hollow is a very simple game, which isn't a bad thing in the slightest, I think it's better that way then trying to be this very complex thing that drags on and becomes overbearing. The gameplay is your standard Turn-Based RPG that isn't anything special but works and isn't relatively broken or incredibly convoluted. One problem I do have is with the "Evade" mechanic. I never really got a good grasp about how to properly evade certain attacks, because when I pressed the button to evade, there was a chance that it doesn't go thru and ends up hurting me. But there there is times where I do evade it, so it basically becomes a guessing game for a very cut and dry mechanic. But this wasn't much of an inconvenience since it barely happened.

This game talks about sorrow and grief. Death is a sad thing that many people struggle with, and this game talks about how it can affect people, how it can change them, for better or for worse. Not everyone can move on from the past. Some people want to return to those times of blissfulness. Some people just don't want to accept that someone they loved is gone. And it's ok to feel grief, it's natural. Some people feel incredibly alone during these times of hardship. But rest assured that, you are not alone. Even if you don't realize it at the moment, you are surrounded by people that love you, and will try to help you and be with you. It's never easy to accept that a loved one is gone, but do know, that the people around you will try to make it a more bearable process. Don't give up.

Overall a pretty good game. The fact that this game is free is incredibly surprising and it feels wrong not paying for it. It's relatively short (2/3 hours), and it's pretty easy to get all of the endings. So give it a try!
7.5/10

123737279.review:
I heard a lot of good things about this game, Not sure if I can recommend it.

> Gameplay: Nothing worthy of Note. Farm Speed and DMG, One-shot everything.
The last boss is easy as well. Just have the 4 buffs up and kill him in no time. No challenge (I played on Normal Mode, there is only one other Mode: Casual. Less fights, and Easier fights. Should have chosen this one as there was no challenge either way. Only waste of time.) But! This is a free game, So what can you say.

> Story: I didn't like it much. Maybe I didn't understand it. The game has 2 Endings. They are not much different beneath the surface, and I think that can teach us a lot about letting go and dealing with Grief of losing someone.

1. The Bad Ending: Her brother is no longer in the Realm of Death with her. She goes crazy, mindlessly farming Ghosts until she passes out of exhaustion. No one dares talk to her. Out of pity, Grimm, an acquaintance of her teleports her to a bed, letting her sleep. She just can't live with the fact that her brother is no longer living. Even if she is dead herself. Even if she can not see him anyway

Even though, she knows that he is living in the After-Life. Such a sad path to take.

2. The Good Ending: She gets the Soul of her brother back, and he goes to live in the Realm of the Living.
No different for her. But she is happy now. She made friends! She tries her best to get stronger in order to get to the afterlife and not be in the Realm of Death (As a reaper) no more.

- See? No difference for her. Either way she can not go back to the Realm of the Living. Either way, she can not see her brother.

But knowing he is in a better place puts her at Ease. The mindset shift aside,
it is no secret that we are going to lose most, if not all of our loved ones someday.

If you are grieving in the Loss of a loved one, specially of they have passed away, just know that they most probably are in a better place.
They most probably are happier. They most probably don't like seeing you going crazy out of pain and doing stupid shit.

All we can do is keep moving forward. Do grief, do cry, do be sad. But don't ever think they are NOT where they should be. For all we know, Death is referred to as a sweet Drink.

Keep Moving Forward, that is what everyone -Specifically Yourself- would want from you, and would make everyone -Specifically Yourself-  happier <3

Overall 9/10. Pick it up - you won't regret it, and on top of that it's free.

The game has very simple timing-dependent, turn-based gameplay design, artstyle, dialogue, and music, but sometimes simple is all you need to convey a good short story and its setting. The gameplay is easy to understand and master, but there is a minor annoyance of the enemy taking their turn while your selection menu is open. Takes less than 3 hours to beat the game and view all possible endings, so it can be a good moment of reprieve from other games or from your daily routine. Other reviewers have mentioned crying after seeing the endings, but I think I'm past that these days with some previous games I played. I was a little sad at the very least seeing how the four endings contrast with each other.

Short, simple, and deathly sweet for the empathetic.

120403736.review:
This is a short game, you'll probably finish it in one sitting. I enjoyed the graphics a lot and the soundtrack was a good fit. The story is straightforward and it's easy to understand what you need to do. You can also understand quite easily what different endings are available and how to get them  (and if not, there are guides available). The big challenge for me was to not get lost in the caves...
I'm not a huge fan of turn-based combat, and there are occasions where the enemies force you to perform a dodge action, so if you're messing around in the menu trying to plan your next attack, it can make you select the wrong action or miss the dodge, which can be frustrating. But there is plenty of free food in the game so you can replenish your health often, and dying isn't really a big deal (unless you're in the final fight, in which case you dying gives you specific endings).
Fun game!

118644010.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1.6 tablespoons unsalted butter 
2. 1/2 cup white sugar 
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 
4. 1/4 cup water 
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt 
7.5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 
8.1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple, filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. 
Allow to cool completely before slicing.

118495099.review:
It's not often that you find a game, a free game on Steam, that looks this polished and this cool. Gameplay-wise it's pretty intuitive even if you don't have that much experience with turn-based combat, the level design is quite charming and easy to navigate without being too obvious with its' secrets; difficulty-wise its' a touch daunting as you start but it doesn't take long to build some confidence and as you progress through the game you don't find yourself in tight corners (at least not any that the game doesn't offer solutions for); as for mechanics it really offers a lot of choices and I can see how it accommodates different playstyles in that way (though admittedly you can be fairly straight forward with it). Story-wise it is a delightful journey through and through, a heartfelt and charming blend of silly and serious without being too over-the-top on either regard (quite careful and friendly with its' subject matter at that), to put it simply, a journey worth having- The game doesn't take long to complete and quite honestly it's worth every minute you give it.

PS. If you want some heartstrings pulled, even more so, I recommend playing with The Evil Within's version of "Clair de Lune" in the background, it adds a whole different atmosphere specially towards the end.

117140870.review:
Really adorable stuff. Hard to think of a more succinct way of summarizing my feelings after playing through it.

The battle mechanics aren't exactly anything flashy, but they more than get the job done. It's satisfying building up your skill tree, even if realistically speaking, you won't be using much more than the standard slash and, occasionally, the Flinch or Sleep spells by the later sections [spoiler]and even during the final boss[/spoiler]. It's all a pretty good foundation to build off of if the devs decide to work on another turn-based RPG at some point in the future.

Story and art direction are the strong suits of Grimm's Hollow. Very endearing setting, with lots of great character designs, and I'd definitely love to see more work from the artists involved. The story itself was very sweet, even if there was more telling than showing than I care for at points, and after getting every ending, I've been left pretty smitten with the protagonist. The one sour note I can think of is that it was a noticeably short experience (I got all of the endings in about 3 hours), but considering that it's entirely free, that's hard to complain about at length.

Very solid all in all. Hope the developers make more games in the future,

115908109.review:
This is quite a small and free game, which you can play through in about 3.5h with all possible endings. It was made with the help of a version of RPG Maker and I think it also has one or two stock sounds. The different characters are very nicely designed and develop a certain personality quite quickly. The landscapes are partly kept quite simple but atmospheric. The dialogs are as expected partly funny and exciting. It's all kept in a certain "Indy style", which generally appeals to me very much. The general sound design was for me personally unfortunately the weakest part of the game. Many effects sounded very generic to me and rather like they served as "gap fillers". Unfortunately, not one of the music pieces that run in the background really stuck in my head. However, this is probably purely personal taste, because the music has obviously been created with a lot of effort and is in no way just some generic droning. While writing this review, I listened to the OST again and unfortunately can't assign any of the melodies to a certain region in the game. The OST was created by Natbird and Bruno Buglisi. The OST is available for free on You Tube, or for fans who want to support the developer, also available on steam with other bits and pieces.

All in all, I really liked the game. Especially the story and the whole visual design appealed to me very much.
I hope the developer Ghosthunter will one day create one or even more games of this kind. I would be very happy about that :)
This game manages in a very short time to "touch" you and make you interested in the depicted world.

I would like to name Untertale as a similar game. Who liked Untertale, will feel quite quickly "back home" :)

I can only recommend this game and fervently hope for more from the developer Ghosthunter. (PLEASE :) )

A wholesome game about grief

I've played a lot of rpg-maker games as a kid and this game stood out to me initially by it's style and charm. Upon playing it I found the writing matched my expectations. What I love most about rpg-maker games is I always seem to find ones that tell a good story and are able to maintain a sensible amount of quirk and silliness. I enjoyed the story, it is very quick.

The combat is nice. I love active time maneuver games and the short mini games for dodging and hitting kept me engaged. The game does get broke after a few hastes however.

I would love to recommend this game to all of my friends who have never played games like these before. It's quickness and charm make for a great introductory into the genre, also the combat is more engaging than most rpg-maker games I've played.

114603764.review:
Everything about Grimm's Hollow is honestly breathtaking. 
I'm an absolute fanatic when it comes to playing pixel art RPG indie style comfort games. If you loved Undertale, Omori, Hollow Knight, or anything similar then you gotta play this!

Being a game that's free I certainly had my doubts, but it certainly doesn't undermine it in any way. 
It so cute, emotional and spooky! Even tho it's short, I got so attached to the characters and the story really made my heart ache. Would definitely play again!

The battles are more fun than difficult, but the mechanics have really smooth animations which enhanced my experience quite a lot. The visuals were so beautiful mixing that cute art style with slight horror elements. It's filled with a deep shaded colour palette of purple, blue, and black which truly fitted the game's aesthetic. Not to mention the OST! Really got that hit of nostalgia back to my first Undertale play-through experience. 

Sorry for the long review, but please take an hour or two out of your day to play this game!

114486575.review:
I'm very happy to see death-positive games on Steam.  First I found A Mortician's Tale, now this.  As a former employee of a funeral home, it makes me glad to see that the idea of death and the afterlife is slowly becoming less scary and more of a topic that people are interested in exploring.

A short but sweet RPG that has a bittersweet story and some fun, memorable characters.  It only takes about two hours to complete, but manages to fit in some interesting mechanics and wonderful artwork that I'd love to see in a larger game in the future.  The game is free, but there is a soundtrack and artbook to support the dev with.  There is some replayability with four endings; thankfully, they all are based on actions you take during the final battle, so it won't take long to 100% the game (although there is one ending that is so brutally abrupt, I was sort of glad I saved it for last...)

Also, there is purple... so much delicious purple.

114449179.review:
An uncut jewel and a tearjerker.
This game is a free to play indie game, and you can tell. It is unpolished and in some places somewhat janky, but it has that clear indie soul.
A wonderfully unique concept, and a fun fighting system with a skill tree. Albeit a little on the easy side, one can really enjoy oneself with it.

The biggest draw however is of course the art and story, both of which are amazing. Throughout the game it has a sweet and pretty artstyle that mixes well with the slight horror elements in the cute world, and every now and then you get painted pictures.
The story is heartbreaking, and might very well make you emotional. I encountered four different endings, all of which were sad, but varied between their secondary emotions. Whether you were made dissapointed, happy, bittersweet or angry.

I recommend this short experience, as i enjoyed it myself.

Cute and Endearing game.  AND it's FREE!!!

Took about shy of 6 hours to finish it and get all the endings.  

******BIG NON-SPOILER TIP THAT YOU DON'T WANT TO MISS OUT ON!!!!******
In order to get ALL endings WITHOUT WASTING TIME REPLAYING the game 4 times make sure to do the following:

1-  DO NOT MAX OUT your skill tree BEFORE making a SAVE that will be accessible later.  I recommend leaving BLUE or RED FLAME at the point where it asks for 60 Points to improve as after that BLUE or RED FLAME will be maxed out.   ONE or THE OTHER.  Just make sure ONE of either BLUE or RED is NOT MAXED OUT.  You can max out all other skills, and attributes.   Also it's a good idea to have VIOLET FLAME MAXED OUT.
2-  BETTER YET DON'T MAX RED or BLUE FLAME UNTIL you get the part with the LAST BOSS.  AT THIS POINT, with your Skill Tree still NOT MAXED OUT create a SAVE GAME that will be accessible later.  It may be a good idea to make sure you also have enough points (which should be 60 if the only thing you didn't max was either RED OR BLUE FLAME) to max your skill tree but DO NOT MAX THEM OUT YET!!!  
3-  FINISH the game for the first time.  AND NOW you can read a guide on how to get all 4 endings, so you won't get spoiled or anything.
4-  This is the part that you will thank yourself for reading my BIG TIP, and following it.
5-  And enjoy your other 3x endings without having to possibly play the game 1-3 more times :)

Grimms Hollow cuenta la historia de una adolescente con la tipica mentalidad y forma de ser adolescente durante todo el juego. Creo que el desarrollador quiere meternos en un mundo con un pensamiento menos maduro, sin embargo, su finalidad sigue siendo salvar a un ser querido.

-La mecánica de combate es divertida, no es tan solo un combate por turnos estilo Final Fantasy.. Hay velocidad, atributos que difieren la mecánica, y te hacen más OP o menos muy muy de acorde al contexto de cada batlla

-Sus horas de juego son muy bajas, este tipo de juegos es lo que tienen. En una tarde te lo haces dos o tres veces si quieres

A small game about accepting death, made in the style of pixel art.
Pass through the gates of the Afterlife with Lavender and her brother Timmy - but first you will need to work hard!
After all, evil ghosts have stolen Timmy's soul, and Lavender herself needs to go a long way to earn her right to leave.
An excellent plot will not leave indifferent many players. The game will appeal to fans of turn-based battles, and localization into many languages, along with accessibility (the game is completely free), will give anyone the opportunity to plunge into the story.
The game is recommended for acquaintance if you are already 14 years old, all the same, questions about life and death are quite difficult for teenagers.

110677150.review:
This is a short but very nice game. After upgrading your character a little bit the turn based combat becomes very easy, I happened to max out my defense right from the start and barely took damage for the entire game. 

My greatest enemy was actually the janky menu more than the mobs - combat doesn't pause for your turn so enemies continue to attack you while you're trying to navigate the menu and just *attack* already. Combined with a very clunky interface that that feels unresponsive because your inputs are locked whenever an enemy's attack animation plays, and that involves many superflous clicks to go through (EG, have to "select a party member" before attacking, when there's only ever the one party member), the menu can make combat slightly frustrating. The rough edges on the menu would be much more forgivable if I didn't have to navigate it on the clock, but it works out in the end because combat is ultimately very easy anyway.

IMO though, this game is much more about it's story than it is about the combat. I think this game came out before Pixar's Soul, but if you've seen that movie, the premise is very similar. Soul was a very good movie. Grimm's Hollow is a very good game. The story is simple and compelling and all of the multiple endings are thorough and satisfying. The story is the heart of this game and it is heartwarming.

Aesthetically the game looks pretty good. They made wise decisions with their limited man power and ended up with some very bang-for-buck art direction. They use a mostly monochrome color palette for example, which means color theory is not a consideration, everything you draw will look good with everything else because it's *all* purple with just a few exceptions. The game is pixel art. The tileset is also mostly solid colors rather than textured details which gives the world a smooth, cartoonish look, and serves to really highlight the things that are given more detail. Icons are cute and simple, wonderfully attractive abstractions. My go-to healing item for the whole game was the ghost cookies because they were just so cute, despite being literally the weakest item. It has very consistent theming, I love the sort of halloween theme it has. I remember about halfway through the game I happened to look at the background of the inventory menu for the first time, and it was a bunch of cute little ghosts and skulls and stuff scrolling by. I thought to myself "Oh hey, that's good! That looks nice, I like this game." Little things made me smile, you know?

The soundtrack is good! I'm super picky about audio transitions, it's a pet peeve of mine when the game loads a new area and the music just cuts abruptly? This game does not do that. Most AAA games do make that mistake, but this little indie game got it right, and I appreciate that. I did find that quickly switching between ambient music and battle music was jarring, but that's a problem every RPG ever has. The sound effect for the "piercing gaze" attack was also irritating, the enemy that does that is my least favorite and I always groaned when finding that one. But these are suuuuper tiny nitpicks, overall the audio is well done.

In conclusion, tiny game made by a tiny team that hits way above it's weight class. Quality craftsmanship and well worth playing. A solid way to spend 3 hours, this is a game I'm happy to have in my Steam Library.

This is honestly a wonderful and attractive game for it being free. I played nonstop for more than 3 hours, and I don't normally do that with story games like this. There were lots of pros to this game, a lot of really nice features, pretty atmosphere, really good music, etc. But there were some cons too.

The fighting is my biggest complaint. It's not really turn based. The enemies you go against can just keep attacking constantly. Even so, a lot of the fights are simply, but they can be really frustrating when you get hit time after time after time by one or two enemies. In one of my sequences, I got hit 15 times (literally, not an exaggeration) before I was finally able to make my turn. Also, the final fight, the additional character that you get to use seems to be a little more in the way than actually useful. They do have their benefit, but it's also not super intuitive and a little messy when actually fighting.

Other than the fighting, I don't have very many gripes with the game. It's adorable, has likable and dislikable characters, and I can't stress how much I liked the music.

Definitely recommend. ALSO - go back and play for the different endings. Make sure you use the saving to your benefit!

108523519.review:
A heartfelt little story about two siblings who died in an accident, going through a crisis on their way to the afterlife.

Visuals: Perfectly adequate, with an exceptionally cute crayon-like artstyle. Nothing looks like 'stock RPG maker asset #6754'. It's all unique, and looks great.
Combat: For the first hour, there is a slight 'challenge' to battles, as Lavender starts out weak. However, by Hour 2 and beyond, you are loaded with items and can defeat most enemies with little to no trouble. Reaching max level for the 'true' ending is an effortless affair. Though I had hoped for at least one enemy or boss- optional or otherwise- that would actually require a few rounds of fighting to defeat, that's clearly not this game's focus or goal, so much as its characters and themes.
Story: An interesting take on Limbo and the afterlife, where the spirits must gather the energy to pass into the true afterlife, or slowly decay into remnants of whatever aspirations they had in life. This is depicted literally through the Baker, [spoiler]whose spirit has remained too long in Limbo, and has begun to turn into a bunch of bread loaves, physically.[/spoiler] 

Clocking in at about 3ish hours of content and free to play, you may as well give it a shot, if you like cute little RPG indies like this.

106307428.review:
Grimm's Hollow is short, but fun and interesting for it's total length.
To avoid spoilers, I will simply mention that there are genuinely interesting characters here who do a decent job of carrying a narrative. The art is charming and pleasant to look at, and the world is somewhat basic but serviceable. The combat is a strong point for this game; while the scale of the game means there are less levels and skills than in a longer game such as final fantasy, there are more than enough to carry the combat throughout the length and be fun while allowing different skill choices. The only drawback to this game is the short run time. The short run time unfortunately hurts the ability for characters and the universe to be fleshed out and explored. While this is fine, and the experience is still very enjoyable, the game and it's premise and characters are so charming that you're left wanting more information and time in the universe.
I highly recommend this game, as it's a free experience that has a lot of enjoyment packed into it, and I hope to see more content from ghosthunter in the future.

Having spent 0 points on skills in the beginning makes the game look tottaly hard an impossible, but with the first few correctly spent points, it will be a piece of cake for experienced players, this until the boss, I got caught with a one shot the first time I fought him, that's because all the damage I had took so far didn't surpassed over 100 hitpoints, so the next time I maxed out the hitpoints and it was a piece of cake again, it's just be careful to not get one hitten with the debuffs the boss gives. There was one detail that caught my attention and I really would like to know the reason behind it: in one of the caves, a waterfall forms a reversed cross, wich can be either an edgy satanic symbol for "cool" kids to show their edgyness and lack of discipline at home, or St. Peter's cross, that means not being whorty of the same death as Jesus Christ. 105856803.review: In my opinion, this game is amazing. So many games today feel like they're more about the money than the game itself. But this one feels like it has a purpose, a goal. It tells a story that pretty much anyone can resonate with. There is love, loss, despair and hope. It was incredibly moving for me to see all the different endings. This game takes about three hours for me the first time around, and in that time it manages to do what a lot of other games can't. It makes you feel something, for every single character in it, no matter how small the part. From the main character, to the "villain" and all the side characters. You hurt for them, and hope for them. The people who made this clearly worked really hard to make it. It was such a small group of people and yet it was so well thought out. There is so much heart to it. I would recommend this game to pretty much anyone for the story alone. If you like games with turn based fights then this one is definitely for you. If you're reading the reviews trying to figure out if this game is worth your time, I'm here to tell you, play it. This game is on the shorter side, and free. Play it. If you do, I really hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

104367225.review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1]
Grimm's Hollow is a game by Mahum Najam, also known as "ghosthunter". It's a turn-based JRPG, think Final Fantasy, or Chrono Trigger. It was released on the 30th of October 2019 and I cannot recommend it enough, there is also something called "Grimm's Hollow: Pocket Goods" under the DLCs section, which is just some extra stuff, like wallpapers for you to support the creator (since the game is 100% free). I highly suggest you support the creator, he's made a really breathtaking experience here.
Without further preamble, here is a list of PRO/CON bullet points.

[h2]PRO:[/h2]
+ Great Music
+ Wonderful Visuals and Animation
+ Great Dialogue
+ Wonderful Tear-Jerker of a Story
+ Nice, if simple, combat
+ Good and Skippable Tutorials
+ Short and Sweet (2 hours)
+ Multiple Endings
+ IT'S FREE!

[h2]CON:[/h2]
- Unstable frame rates (at least in fullscreen mode, I think the game may not be optimised for it)
- Slightly floaty controls (but not in combat, since it's turn-based, which is all that matters)
- Powers are unbalanced, as in, you don't really need to use most of them (just levelling up HP and ATK will probably get you through most of the game) - the exception to this point is the final boss (you really need everything here)

103183863.review:
Esta critica tiene spoilers, primero juega al juego que la vas a pasar... Y luego ves todo lo que me he sacado. No es una guía de compras.

Esto es la mejor historia contada de la mejor manera que he visto. Trata de una adolescente que ha muerto y que está ahora en un lugar extraño y con temática oscura.

a lo que me refiero con "buen contada" es por lo que pude sacar sobreanalizando el título, primero me dí cuenta de que la historia tenía algo más escondido de lo que estaba por la escena en la que la chica nos cuenta a nosotros y al mismo tiempo a su hermano lo que pasó antes de su muerte. La chica es una adolescente que sus padres pasaban por una mala situación económica, y ella tenía que quedarse en casa y hacer los queaceres. Sus padres se peleaban muy seguido, se maltrataban y gritaban. sus peleas habían sesado, su situación economica era buena, pero su padre murió. Esto le pegó demasiado duro a la protagonista, pero antes de morir había dejado embarazada a su madre, y así nació el pequeño timmy. Un niño inocente, al que lala (la protagonista) le encantaba jugar con él cuando tenía tiempo libre. su madre quería mucho a Timmy, dejando de lado a lala, pero a lala no le importó... Ella no había recibido amor de sus padres. De lo único que recibía y daba amor, era de su hermano... En esta parte lloré como un puto niño, pero ahora hay más. lala quiere darle un alma a su hermano, no le interesa revivir ella, ya no le interesa nada más que su hermano. Pensar esto realmente me pegó tan duro que lloré 10 minutos de las 2.5 hs que jugué al juego. Yo saqué el final malo, en el que el panadero se llevó el alma de timmy y se convirtió en un mutante. por lo que grimm tuvo que sacrificarlo. Lala lloraba y lloraba por la muerte de su hermano. Una cosa que noté es que por el poco amor que recibía Lala de sus padres, ella representa a los fantasmas del juego cómo sus pensamientos a sí misma. hay un monstruo que es un reloj, que he representado que es la manera en que ella se vé, una perdida de tiempo... No solo me baso en ese monstruo, tambien en otro que es un parasito que veo como si ella pensara que es el parásito de la familia. Lala cuando termina un combate no está cansada por lo que tuvo que hacer, sinó que representa como se siente. 
Otra cosa que encontré es que cada vez la música se pone más oscura. Lo tomo como la decadencia de la mente de Lala, que ella solo quería salvar a su hermano, lo único que le importaba. Y con todas las dificultades que se le ponen, se va desanimando más y más. 
El uso del color es 10/10 de este juego. Al principio al parecer una historia conmovedora y con mucho carisma, todo es colorido. Hay globos coloridos, las habitaciones son bonitas, la cueva está hecha de colores vivos, y al final todo se torna gris, oscuro.
una cosa que noté es que el color oscuro en los ojos de Lala es la falta de amor que tiene. Y que poco y nada le importa ya su vida.
Lala quiere redimirse, sentír que su existencia ha valido de algo, esa es otra razon de porque Lala quiere salvar a su hermano.
Luego de esto que pasó al final del final malo, grimm nos cuenta como actuó Lala posteriormente. Solo se dedicaba a matar monstruos, a veces se quedaba pensando en frente de una cueva. Todos le tenían miedo. Cuando la recogía y la dejaba en una cama luego de que se desmayara, desaparecía en cuanto salia de la habitación. Grimm quería volverla a la vida, pero ni el podía hacer eso sin perjudicar a un alma. Es un final muy melancolico.
Ahora que me he pasado el final bueno, Timmy logra tener el alma, todo parece tener un tono humorístico. Hasta que Timmy debe irse, y se da cuenta de que Lala le ha mentido sobre que ella iría con él. Termina accediendo a irse y joder estoy llorando que mierda me pasa? acabo de conocer este juego hace 3 horas joder 
Luego de esta escena, Lala se "medio abre" ante grimm y luego proceden a irse.
Ahora sucede algo extraño, en vez de relatarnos lo que ocurre grimm, nos lo relata Lala. Lala nos cuenta que se perdió en las cuevas, esperando a "pasar", hasta que Grimm finalmente la encuentra y la deja en la cama del principio. Nos cuentan una realidad mucho mejor a lo que vimos antes, Grimm aprende a tejer, ya no hay panadero, y Grimm decide hacer un sueter de Timmy para recordarlo con cariño, lavender llora por su hermano perdido, desea verlo otra vez. Ella confunde la realidad que vivió antes de la muerte como un sueño, y su vida actual como la realidad. Grimm actúa de una forma divertida y bastante paterna con ella. 

Saltan los títulos... Y este juego pasa a ser mi recuerdo más añorado en un videojuego, pero odio tener que finalmente llamarlo "recuerdo".  Nos muestran a Lavender siendo feliz con grimm, y aunque con tristeza, admito que estoy satisfecho.

Mahun Najam, Siento que te he robado, perdoname. Y hazlo de pago.

102688476.review: I usually don't write reviews but I wanted to give this one the exposure.  This scratched that RPG Maker itch perfectly with pleasing visuals, decent combat, and a nice little story that's too the point and doesn't overstay its welcome.  I think my favorite part of the whole thing came down to some of the sound effects in battles, since they use the same hit sounds that are in OFF (I'm pretty sure, at least - it's fitting unless it's some default noise).  I kinda wish that the combat required more of you, since there's a lot of moves that I simply just didn't end up using because it was easier to use the instant kill moves.  The only time I really considered using the other moves is in the last fight, where the status effects are basically required.  Really though, the game is more focused on its atmosphere and story, so it doesn't really bog down the experience.  I got the bad end and true end; both were pretty satisfying.  If you have the time give it a shot; it's free, and what's more, it's good.

102647896.review:
Realising that I'm a really big fan of the RPGmaker aesthetic because of games like this. I love looking at games and how they can be designed around certain constraints, seeing what interesting ideas are brought to the forefront to be conducive to both a great experience and one that doesn't compromise in its vision. In this case, it seems like the entire goal of the game was to craft an emotionally moving, character driven story while only having around 2 hours of gameplay, give or take, and I'd say that in this regard, Grimm's Hollow is a resounding success. The game is shockingly good at providing very clear and interesting pieces of characterisation that rapidly inject a lot of charm and colour into the world, all main characters having extremely clear and nuanced elements to their individual motives, a bunch of genuinely funny lines, just a bit of everything to give them just enough unique traits to feel distinct and interesting while still shrouding them in enough mystery to keep them intriguing, even once the game ends.

To add to this, the narrative in general is short yet very effective in its portrayal of attempting to process grief and everything that comes along with it in a variety of ways that naturally act as a way to ramp the tension and stakes. I love the way the music becomes so intense as things go on until it hits a point where it completely plateaus into a series of long winded, droning melodies that feel as if they represent the true reality of the situation setting in. Likewise, the use of colour feels pretty interesting, with the vaguely warm and cool colours of blue and purple being gradually phased out for a much harsher red, which cleverly manages to establish a much more intense feeling that once again feels as if it's then cleverly phased out to a more neutral series of greys and whites.

On top of the excellent, charming writing, I also really appreciated the combat once I got into it, being fairly simple and easy, but providing a lot of variety in what way you could choose to build your character and approach any given situation, having to carefully consider where to dump your resources for whatever potentially dangerous situation is ahead. The little timing based elements also kept it that bit fresher feeling, even if those mechanics were ultimately pretty shallow and felt as if they really should have had some nicer feedback associated with them to feel as polished as so many other elements here, but they did the trick enough to only rarely be a distraction. Overall this is just a really solid little game that does a lot with its short runtime and feels like an extremely well oiled machine with so much heart behind it. Definitely play this if you're at all into RPGmaker aesthetics or charming, occasionally quirky narrative experiences.

8/10
